Message.Msg: Their real revenue will most likely be light but due to a business change it may be reported as $600M-$700M above estimates. the reality in real terms that could be $300M-$400M light since it's all new accounting of the e-publishing business where the same revenue could be counted as $1B more due to a business change and not any revenue growth. Message.Title: I Will Post My Next Prediction on Wednesday Evening
Message.Msg: At this point I'm thinking of selling close to the money puts and also selling close to the money calls on Thursday afternoon (10/25 expiration). AMZN already ran up a lot in sympathy with GOOG, so another giant leg up doesn't seem likely. And though it should be trading much lower, the environment doesn't seem right yet for a return to a reasonable valuation. So the option sellers might win this time. I'll keep an eye on things the next couple days and let everyone know what to do on Wednesday night. So far, none of the predictions I've posted here have failed to come true. Thanks for your support.

Topic.Title: Walmart: AMZN is playing loss game to wait out competition

Message.Msg: Not as long as Wall Street continues to fund this "profitless growth.'' Now there's a term that AMZN has truly invented. Without the backing of the FED and the Wall Street cartel, AMZN would have to fund it's expansion attempts through actual cash flow. Of which AMZN has precious little. AMZN funds it's expansion through stock sales and borrowing more and more from suppliers. It has no net cash, since it owes suppliers over 10 billion. It has already borrowed in the traditional sense once, over 3 billion to waste on fancy headquarters and more worthless initiatives. That money is gone, and AMZN is likely to line up for another tranche in early 2014. Another 3 billion so quick might get Wall Street's attention, but probably not. As long as the FED continues to pump 85 billion a month into "financial assets" that can't productively use the capital, AMZN will be there like a sponge to sop it up. BTW, their numbers on Thursday will be terrible, but it may not matter.

Topic.Title: Rats leaving the sinking ship

Message.Msg: Unfortunately for AMZN pumpers and those Scamalysts who have blindly pumped (and raised price targets despite the current cash position and burn rate), math is a biyatch sometime. The required inventory AND labor to deliver a given service level increases as a percent of total as the number of FC increases. That is why profits are disappearing. The narrative on shipping cost isn't supported by the facts. Gross shipping cost as a % of net sales has gone up and only internal revenue transfers from Prime reduced net shipping cost. But, even there, the benefit plateaued because it is about the LAST mile (which is why co-locating with P&G and others hasn't solved the problems either...). The AMZNatic is sinking. Last week, quants unloaded the most important passengers via the upper deck. Regular 401K holders will be left below deck to go down with the ship. This is where things get really fun. Let's see who's maneuvering to run the book. AMZN will need another offering to maintain its "investment" and its "growth".
